content:
Can someone edit to replace "loose" by "lose"?
Thanks.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Original, nice visualization

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A nice puzzle.
The comments made by Djoums and me were addressed, so I'll gladly approve

mouton5000 this looks like a great solo game and I'd love to see you address and reply to Djoums comments.  After addressing them, please respond to this message so I'll get notified and I'll review again.  This game will be very helpful for people to practice their binary tree and search knowledge, so please keep at it!

Some feedback :
* bombsSize -> bombCount, goalsSize -> goalCount, loose -> lose
* By convention the point (0, 0) is always the top left point in a grid, but here you chose to set y = 0 at the bottom. Any good reason for it ?
* The height of the grid is not given directly in the input, which is tedious to deal with when you don't have access to dynamically sized arrays.
* Because the root is always at the bottom center, some of the displayed circles are never used, there's no way to "reach" them.

Overall it's a good puzzle but it needs some polish.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Some more thoughts now that I've solved it:
My bruteforce didn't pass, what I consider a good thing. I ended up generating valid trees and assigning values at the end to match the structure.
There are 7 IDE testcases but only 1 submit validator.
The first testcase can be solved with only 3 numbers but n=4.

Address these points as well as those of my previous comment, then I'll gladly approve.

An interesting contribution that unfortunately got buried in the list of clashes.

I managed to crash the referee by causing an int overflow.
And I'd like to see a print statement in the default code.

Apart from that this contribution looks approvable on a first look (I haven't tried to solve it yet, only hardcoded to see if it works)

Hi
Thanks a lot for looking at my contribution.

I'll add the print statement as soon as possible.
Can you give me the code you used for the int overflow? Did you just print a lot of ints ? Or maybe it is a classical mistake for which there is a classical fix ? (This is the first contribution I make with the referee so there may be some conventions/good practice I don't have).

Ok, thanks again for the comments. 

I added the print statement ("write 1").
I added the NumberFormatException.

The test case 1 with n = 4 but only 3 needed numbers is wanted. You are allowed to not use all the integers from 1 to n.

Finally, there are indeed some missing testcases and validators (they were mixed and I forgot some instances). I'll add them as soon as possible.

Dear Djoums

Thanks for your feedback. And sorry for the delay, I saw your message when you posted it and I then forgot to reply. I should have some time to update the game before tomorrow. 

For the point (0, 0), the convention is true for computer scientists, not for mathematicians :) In any case, if you think this is disturbing, I can just invert the drawing. 

Ok for the height. 

Yeah, some circles are not used, I can gray them on the drawing if you think it would be better.

Thank you for your comment that woke me up after 20 days :)

I made all the requested changes.
Ok, I think I addressed all your requests.

I just tested a number outside of the 32bit range: 123123123123.
You probably catch a TimeoutException somewhere. Add a NumberFormatException and you are fine.
